SENT.plain: Although Hedgehog (HH) signaling plays a major role in GLI1 transcription, there is now evidence suggesting that other pathways/genes, such as c-MYC, may also regulate GLI1 expression
We initiated studies in Burkitt lymphoma cells, which constitutively express c-MYC due to a chromosomal translocation, to determine if HH or c-MYC regulates GLI1 expression
We show that all Burkitt lymphoma cell lines tested express GLI1, PTCH1, and SMO, and that 5/6 Burkitt lymphomas express GLI1
Exposure to Sonic or Indian HH or cyclopamine (SMO inhibitor) does not modulate GLI1 expression, cell proliferation or apoptosis in most Burkitt lymphoma cell lines
Sequence analysis of PTCH1, SMO and SuFu failed to demonstrate mutations that might explain the lack of HH responsiveness, and we did not detect primary cilia, which may contribute to it
We demonstrate that c-MYC interacts with the 5'-regulatory region of GLI1, using ChIP assay, and E-box dependent transcriptional activation of GLI1 by c-MYC in NIH3T3 and HeLa cells
The c-MYC small molecular inhibitor 10058-F4 down-regulates GLI1 mRNA and protein and reduces viability of Burkitt lymphoma cells
Inhibition of GLI1 by GANT61 increases apoptosis and reduces viability of some Burkitt lymphoma cells
Collectively, our data provide evidence that c-MYC directly regulates GLI1 and support an anti-apoptotic role for GLI1 in Burkitt lymphoma
Burkitt lymphoma cells do not appear to be HH responsive
These findings suggest a mechanism for resistance to SMO inhibitors and have implications for using SMO inhibitors to treat human cancers
